snippet: Given a choice of two males, a female will pick the most attractive. But, researchers say, that’s not necessarily the case when a third male is added.
abstract: Study published in journal Science finds that female tungara frogs will choose less attractive of first two male options if third inferior male is added to the mix; research suggests that frogs make irrational mate selections when social situation becomes overly complex.
lead_paragraph: Given a choice of two males, a female will pick the most attractive. But, researchers say, that’s not necessarily the case when a third male is added.

headline.print_headline: Amphibians: A Twist to How a Túngara Frog Finds Her Prince
headline.main: A Twist to How a Túngara Frog Finds Her Prince
